annotation.TEXT: Shark Boomerang is the only other weapon in the game (aside from Razor Blade) with any type of vertical range. It can be fired forwards, or diagonally up and down. Aside from having the usual trait of returning to you after fired (except when it goes off-screen), it can also pick up items and bring them back to you.

As far as I can tell, Sonic Reflector didn't seem to get any major changes. It's probably the most lack-luster of the weapons in the game, but it still manages to have its uses here and there (mainly as boss weakness affiliations).

At this point, I also have to apologize for all the blaring buster sound effects. Although I managed to lower the audio to a pretty decent level, the sound for the buster hitting anything seems to be way too loud regardless. Even if you lower the game's sound output by 50% in audio mixer, it still manages to be pretty loud.

As you can probably tell, the water physics are a little weird at times. Even if you're standing above the water, you'll still jump as though you were submerged. Thankfully, this isn't that much of a problem (similar to the oil/fire in Oil Man's stage, this particular - probably unintentional - quirk is only really found in this stage).

Oh hey, Nitro Man's theme remained in the game (and it's certainly more fitting for this stage than Dive Man's theme). On that note, I can understand being turned off due to the fact that this game uses songs from the original series. I can agree with that in most regards...but then again, I really like Nitro Man's theme, so I don't have much of a reason to complain this time around.

I'm not sure if Flame Rush was buffed or not, but whatever the case, I see it as a viable weapon this time around. Aside from the smaller fireballs it spews out around you, the main projectile itself is decently powerful, and is capable of taking down a good portion of the enemy cast in one or two uses (not to mention it can easily pierce through weaker enemies, such as Suzies).

Similar to MM9, getting hit with oil will coat you in it, making your movements more slippery. In relation to this, the Flame Rush is also capable of igniting oil as well (granted, it's an aspect that only seems to play a major part in this particular stage, but it's still something to be mindful of).

Oil Igniter can be a bit odd to get used to (mainly when using it in the water, since it floats upwards), but it does have one unique trait about it: Hitting/destroying things with it generally seems to produce items, making it somewhat like a projectile-version of the Recycle Inhaler from 4MI.

Junk Golems are still pretty tanky in this game, but their method of attacking is far less annoying this time around. They mostly interact with the environment by throwing small junk blocks dispensed from above, which always come out in a set arc (rather than being aimed directly at you).
